Afghanistan.passage: Afghanistan (/ˌæfændʒəˈrɑːndeɡ/ ( listen) AF-jər-ən-dəɡ or /-ˈɡærfən/ ( listen) (-d͡ʒærfən) (Afx-ərj-an-dəɡ, Afx-ər-gərn, Af-JEHR-awn-də-k, Af-JUR-awn-dəg) is a country located in Central Asia. It is bordered by Pakistan in the east and northeast, Iran in the west, Turkmenistan in the northwest, China in the north and Tajikistan in the southwest. It has a population of about 33 million. The capital is Kabul. The official languages of Afghanistan are Pashto and Dari (known as Afghan Persian or Dari). The country's religion is Islam, practiced by 95% of the population. The majority of Afghans follow Sunni Islam and a significant minority follow Shi'a Islam. The territory now known as Afghanistan has been inhabited since the Bronze Age.

Albania.passage: Albania ( /ˌɑːlˈbiəniə/ AL-bli-ə-nnee-ə; Albanian: [aˈlbanɛɾja]), officially the Republic of Albania ( /ˌɑːlbaniə/ AL-bə-NI-ə; Albanian: Republika e Shqipërisë), is a country in the Balkan Peninsula in Southeast Europe. It has a border with the Mediterranean Sea to the west and the Adriatic Sea to the north, while it borders on Greece and the Republic of Macedonia to the south. To its east is Montenegro; to its northwest is Kosovo, which is disputed with Albania. The capital and largest city is Tirana, with a population of around 1.7 million people. Albania has a diverse terrain that features a largely mountainous landscape in the north but also includes a large plain in the south that was once covered by the now-extinct Tethys Ocean. The climate is typically Mediterranean in the coastal areas and continental in the interior. A majority of the population is ethnic Albanian, with other significant ethnic groups including Greeks, Italians, Slavic Macedonians, Montenegrins, and Turks. The country has a population of 3.03 million, and is a democratic and developing country with an upper-middle income economy.

Andorra.passage: Andorra is a sovereign country located in the Pyrenees mountains between France and Spain. The country has a population of about 85,000 people, and the capital is Andorra la Vella. The principality is bordered by Spain to the north, France to the east and south, and the Mediterranean Sea to the west. The country has an area of 468 square kilometres (181 sq mi) and a largely mountainous terrain. Andorra is a parliamentary republic with a president and a unicameral parliament. Andorra is divided into four parishes. The parish of Encamp is the largest, followed by the parish of La Massana, Sant Julià de Lòria, and Escaldes-Engordany. Andorra is divided into seven parishes. The largest is Encamp, followed by La Massana, Sant Julià de Lòria, and Escaldes-Engordany. The capital of Andorra la Vella is the largest town in Andorra. Andorra la Vella is the largest town in the country, with the largest church in the world, the Church of the Holy Saviour, which is located on top of the highest point in the country. Angola.passage: Angola (/ˌɒŋəˈɡoʊlə/; Portuguese: [ɐŋɡwla]) officially the Republic of Angola (Portuguese: República de Angola; [reˈpuβliða ɐŋɡwla]), is a country in southern Africa bordered by Namibia to the northwest, Zambia to the northeast, the Democratic Republic of the Congo to the east and south, and the Atlantic Ocean to the west. It is the seventh-largest country in Africa and is home to over 20 million people. Angola has a very young population, with more than half of Angolans being younger than 14, and a median age of 17.2 years, one of the youngest in the world. The Angolan Civil War (1975-2002) was the longest civil war in the 20th century, lasting 27 years. The war ended in 2002, with the Angolan Armed Forces, backed by the United Nations and the government of South Africa, prevailing over the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA) and the National Liberation Front of Angola (FNLA). The capital and largest city of Angola is Luanda, which has a population of over 3.8 million. The second most populous city in Angola is Huambo. Other major cities include Benguela and Lubango.

Antigua and Barbuda.passage: The capital city of the island of Antigua and Barbuda is St. John's, which has a population of around 30,000. Antigua and Barbuda is a two island country in the Eastern Caribbean, approximately 90 miles (145 km) north east of Puerto Rico. Antigua and Barbuda has a population of around 100,000, with the majority of the population living on its larger island, Antigua. The country is divided into five parishes, each of which has a parish seat. The five parishes are Barbuda, Saint John, Saint Mary, Saint Paul, Saint Peter. The island is home to many forts and fortifications, including the world's oldest standing lighthouse, the Barbuda lighthouse, which is over 300 years old. The island has many beaches including the world's second-longest beach, Jolly Harbour Beach, which is over 4 miles long (6 km). The island's capital is St. John's, which has a population of around 30,000.

Argentina.passage: Arguably the most important Argentine cultural figure in the 20th century, Jorge Luis Borges (1899–1986) was an acclaimed poet, short-story writer, essayist, translator, and literary critic. He is widely regarded as one of the most influential Latin American writers, and is often compared to such contemporaries as Thomas Mann, Franz Kafka, and Albert Camus. Borges's literary career encompassed an exceptionally wide variety of styles, forms, and themes. He is considered one of the most important writers of short stories in the Spanish language, and one of the most important writers of short stories in general, and his work has had a significant influence on Latin American literature. Borges was a polymath with an encyclopedic range of interests. He produced important scholarly work on medieval Spanish literature and was a pioneering scholar of the Aztec language Náhuatl. He was a leading authority on the works of William Shakespeare and an avid student of English and Scottish literature. His knowledge of English, French, and Italian was encyclopedic, and he translated works by such authors as Edgar Allan Poe, Jonathan Swift, and Charles Dickens into Spanish. His essays and literary criticism covered a wide range of subjects, including Aztec mythology, Kafka, Shakespearean drama, the works of Honoré de Balzac, and the novels of Charles Dickens. He also composed poetry in English, French, Italian, Latin, and Spanish.

qae_pairs.question: Who is the person who wrote the book "Ficciones"?
qae_pairs.explanation: Jorge Luis Borges (1899–1986) was an acclaimed poet, short-story writer, essayist, translator, and literary critic. He is widely regarded as one of the most influential Latin American writers, and is often compared to such contemporaries as Thomas Mann, Franz Kafka, and Albert Camus.

qae_pairs.question: What is the birth year of the person who was a leading authority on the works of William Shakespeare?
qae_pairs.explanation: Jorge Luis Borges was born in 1899–1986.

Armenia.passage: Armenia (Հայաստան, Հայկազանիա), officially the Republic of Armenia (Հայաստանի Հանրապետություն), is a landlocked country in the South Caucasus region, situated between Eastern Turkey and the Republic of Georgia. It is bordered by Turkey to the west, Azerbaijan and Nagorno-Karabakh to the north, Georgia to the northeast, and Iran and Azerbaijan to the east. The territory of modern-day Armenia has been inhabited by humans since at least 10,000 BC. The area was first unified by the ancient Kingdom of Armenia between c. 4th and 6th centuries AD. The ancient Armenian kingdom fell to Arab Muslims in the 7th century, then ruled by the Bagratid and Karsid rulers, and by the Mongol Empire in the 13th-15th centuries. Following the fall of the Russian Empire in 1917 and subsequent collapse of the Russian Caucasus Army in 1918, the First Republic of Armenia was proclaimed. Between 1918 and 1920, the state fought against invading forces from the west and the east. It was subsequently partitioned by the neighboring countries, with the western part becoming a sovereign country, the Republic of Turkey.

qae_pairs.question: Which empire conquered the Kingdom of Armenia?
qae_pairs.explanation: The Mongol Empire conquered the Kingdom of Armenia.

qae_pairs.explanation: Azerbaijan

Australia.passage: Australia (Australian and British English) or Australia (US English) is a country comprising the mainland of the Australian continent, the island of Tasmania and numerous smaller islands. Australia has a varied climate, with warm to hot temperatures in the north alternating with cool to cold temperatures in the south. Australia's proximity to the equator means that there are significant seasonal changes, with warm to hot temperatures in the summer and cool to cold temperatures in the winter, although subtropical areas are not subject to extreme seasonal temperature variations. With a total area of around 7,617,930 square kilometres (2,861,410 sq mi), Australia is the world's sixth-largest country by total area. It is the world's second-largest island country after Great Britain, and the largest country made up of entirely continental landmass. Australia's capital is Canberra, and its largest urban area is Sydney. With a population of around 25.5 million people, Australia is the world's 12th-largest country by population, and the largest country by area in Oceania, and the southern hemisphere. The Australian continent began to form some time between 55 and 70 million years ago, arising from a split in the ancient supercontinent Gondwana. Over the next 30 million years Australia broke away from the southern continent of Gondwana and drifted north and eventually separated from Antarctica, completing the process around 47 million years ago.

qae_pairs.question: In what season is the country that is made up of the mainland of the Australian continent, the island of Tasmania and numerous smaller islands located?
qae_pairs.explanation: In the summer, Australia has warm to hot temperatures.

qae_pairs.explanation: The capital of Australia is Canberra.

qae_pairs.explanation: The city of Sydney, Australia, has a population of over 5 million people.

Austria.passage: Austria (German: Österreich, pronounced [ˈøstɐʁiːɐ̯]; Slovene: Avstria, pronounced [ˈavːstriːa]; Croatian: Avstrija, pronounced [avːstriːa]; Italian: Austria, pronounced [ˈøstːriːa]; Hungarian: Avstriaság, pronounced [ˈavstriːasːɒg]; Polish: Austria, pronounced [ˈøstːrʲiːa]; Czech: Rakousko, pronounced [ˈrakuːsko]; Slovak: Rakovsko, pronounced [raˈkovsko]; Ukrainian: В’юрії́на (V’yhriýna), pronounced [vʏ́ˈrjjaˌna]; Rusyn: В’о́стрья (V’ostr’ya), pronounced [vʏ́ˈstrʲja]), officially the Republic of Austria (German: Republik Österreich, pronounced [ˈreːpʊblik ɔˈʃteːriːə]), is a landlocked country in Central Europe, situated in Western and Central Europe.

the Bronze Age.passage: The Bronze Age was a period in the 3rd to 2nd millennia BC, roughly coinciding with the rise of urban civilization and the development of bronze as a hard-working metal. The Bronze Age was preceded by the Chalcolithic or Copper Age and followed by the Iron Age.

qae_pairs.question: How many years did the Bronze Age last?
qae_pairs.explanation: The Bronze Age lasted for roughly 3,000 years.

Pakistan.passage: Pakistan (; Urdu: پاکستان, lit. \"land (country) of the (pure) people\"; [pʰəˌkʰɑːˌstæn] or [pʰəˌskʰɑːˌstæn]) is a country in South Asia. It is the sixth-most populous country, with over 200 million people. It is the 42nd-largest country by total area, spanning. It is bordered to the northwest by Afghanistan and to the northeast by China in the remote and complex Himalayan region, which covers one-fifth of its territory. Pakistan has a 1,046-kilometre coastline along the Arabian Sea and the Gulf of Oman in the south and is the only country that borders both the Indian and the Pacific Oceans in the world. Pakistan has a mountainous topography and is home to many diverse natural landscapes. It is home to the world's second-largest mountain range, the Himalayas, and the world's third-largest desert, the Thar.

China.passage: China, officially the People's Republic of China (PRC), is a sovereign state in East Asia. It is the world's second-largest country by land area and the most populous state. The capital is Beijing, and the largest city is Shanghai. China's major urban areas include Hong Kong and Tianjin. China is the world's oldest continuous unified civilization, and is one of the world's oldest continuing civilizations, tracing its roots back five millennia. One of the world's first civilizations, it is considered one of the cradles of human civilization. China's history is characterized by state-of-the-art achievements in the arts, technology, and warfare, and by the development of influential philosophical schools of thought, including Confucianism, Taoism, and Legalism.

Dari.passage: In English, it is sometimes spelled Darī or Darri. In Arabic, it is pronounced [dʒaˈriː] (Darij). The name of the language is derived from the name of the Dardae, an ancient people who inhabited the area of the Indo-Gangetic Plain in the second millennium BC.

Shi'a Islam.passage: Shi'a Islam, also known in Arabic as "Shia Islam" (حِــــوِْ ٱـــسِْ ــــلِّّٰـمِيَّـــتُون),[a] is the second largest denomination of Islam. It has an estimated 85–90% of the global total of Muslims, and is followed by 9–11% of the global population. Shi'a Islam has been the largest denomination of Islam since the 9th century, and is the largest denomination in Iran and Iraq. The majority of the world's Shiites live in those two countries.

Kosovo.passage: Kosovo (Albanian: Kosova; Serbian: Косово; Turkish: Kosova; Macedonian: Косово), officially the Republic of Kosovo ( /ˈkɒzvɔː/ KOH-zhoo-voh), is a landlocked country in Southeastern Europe that constitutes roughly 37% of Serbia's territory and has a population of 1.85 million. It is bordered by Albania to the northwest, Montenegro to the northeast and Macedonia to the east. It has a border with Northern Kosovo across the Ibar river, which separates it from the Republic of Serbia proper to the west. The capital city is Pristina, and the largest city is Prizren. Kosovo has a high level of ethnic diversity, with Albanians, Serbs, Bosniaks, Roma, Turks and other groups represented. Kosovo is home to many monasteries and churches, the best known of which are the Studenica monastery complex, the Morača monastery and the Visoki Decani monastery. It is the seat of the Serbian Orthodox Church, headed by the Primate of the Serbian Orthodox Church. Kosovo has a special administrative status within the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and the State Union of Serbia and Montenegro. It was envisaged as a self-governing province within the federal state, and was granted a large degree of political autonomy.

qae_pairs.explanation: Pristina is the capital city of Kosovo.

the Mediterranean Sea.passage: The sea has a total area of about 2,575,000 km2 (983,000 sq mi) and a maximum depth of about 5,429 m (17,408 ft). It is connected to the Atlantic Ocean by the Strait of Gibraltar and the Suez Canal, to the Black Sea and to the Arctic Ocean via the Bosporus and the Turkish Straits. the Balkan Peninsula.passage: The Balkan Peninsula, also known as the Balkans (Balkanization), is a peninsula and a subregion of Europe, located between the Adriatic and the Black Sea, and between the Mediterranean and the Danube. It is more commonly defined as the south-easternmost protrusion of Eurasia, separated by the water from Italy to the northwest, the rest of the European continent to the northeast, and the Caucasus and Anatolia to the south. The peninsula consists of seven mutually interconnected and non-contiguous countries: Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Greece, Romania and Serbia.

qae_pairs.explanation: The Balkan Peninsula is located between the Adriatic and the Black Sea, and between the Mediterranean and the Danube.

Spain.passage: Spain (Spanish: España [esˈpaɫa]), officially the Kingdom of Spain, is a country in south-western Europe, primarily situated on the Iberian Peninsula. It is the second largest country by area in Europe and the fifth largest in the European Union. It is bordered to the south and east by the Mediterranean Sea; to the north and west by the Atlantic Ocean; and by Portugal to the southwest. The Strait of Gibraltar is at Spain's southern tip, with an area of 36,360 km2 (14,000 sq mi), making it the narrowest point between the Atlantic and the Mediterranean. France.passage: France (i/fɔrˈʃɛə/ (listen); French: (ʁɑ̃s)fʁɛːʁ [ʁãsfɚ]), officially the French Republic, is a country whose territory consists of metropolitan France in Western Europe and several overseas regions and territories. The metropolitan area of France extends from the Mediterranean Sea to the English Channel and the North Sea, and from the Atlantic Ocean to the Rhine. France's territory includes metropolitan France in Europe, as well as several overseas regions and territories in Africa and the Indian and Pacific Oceans. France's national territory includes some land in North Africa and the Middle East. France's population is about 67 million people, making it the world's fourth-largest country by population and the world's sixth-largest country by area. It is also the European country with the second-largest number of international students, as well as one of the largest exporters of cultural goods. The territory of France has been connected to surrounding regions by a system of roads since the Middle Ages, and expanded through conquest in the Early Middle Ages and later colonization. France's location at the crossroads of Western Europe makes it a major regional power, with a significant cultural, political, and military influence in the world.

the Church of the Holy Saviour.term: the Church of the Holy Saviour
the Church of the Holy Saviour.passage: Church of the Holy Saviour is a historic church on the east side of the South Congregational Church in South Hadley, Massachusetts. It was built in 1846 and added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1984. It has been known as South Congregational Church, as the Church of the Holy Savior, as the United Church of Christ, and as the United Church. It is a rare example of a 19th-century Gothic Revival church in New England, and is architecturally significant. It was built by members of the South Hadley Society for the Religious and Moral Improvement of Youth, who were dissatisfied with the Congregational Church. It was originally located on Main Street, but was moved to its present location in 1896. It is a part of the South Hadley Historical Society. The building is now owned by the United Church of Christ. The church building is a rare surviving example of Gothic Revival church architecture in New England, and is a significant local landmark.

the Democratic Republic of the Congo.passage: The Democratic Republic of the Congo, officially known as the Republic of the Congo (French: République démocratique du Congo or RDC), is a country in Central Africa. The country is bordered by the Republic of the Congo to the west, Gabon to the southwest, Cameroon to the northwest, Central African Republic to the northeast, the South Sudan to the east, Tanzania to the southeast, and Zambia to the south. The Democratic Republic of the Congo covers an area of, and is slightly larger than France. It is home to a population of over 77 million people, the largest in Africa. The capital city is Kinshasa. The Democratic Republic of the Congo is bordered by the Republic of the Congo to the west, Gabon to the southwest, Cameroon to the northwest, Central African Republic to the northeast, the South Sudan to the east, Tanzania to the southeast and Zambia to the south. Jorge Luis Borges.passage: Jorge Luis Borges (English pronunciation: /bɔːrˈkɛs/; Spanish: [ˈβɔɾˈkes]; June, 1875 – August, 1986) was an Argentine writer, poet, and literary critic best known for his short stories, essays, and poetry, which have had a significant influence on the development of literature and philosophy. Borges' writings, which include more than thirty books, have been translated into many languages and have attained iconic status in the Spanish-speaking world. He was nominated for the International Prize for Arabic Literatur e and the Jerusalem Prize. He was described as "the greatest literary figure in the Spanish-speaking world" by Harold Bloom. Borges began his literary career as a poet but is best known for his short stories, including "The Garden of Forking Paths", which blend fantasy and reality in literary works that are often labyrinthine and play on the borderlines of literature. His other works include the essays "The Aleph" and "A New Refutation of Time". Borges also wrote poetry, which has been compared to that of Walt Whitman and William Carlos Williams. Borges was a member of the Argentine literary group "Los Nuevos" and a correspondent for the Parisian literary review "Sur".

qae_pairs.question: Which prize was awarded to Jorge Luis Borges?

the Mongol Empire.passage: The Mongol Empire (Mongol: "Улс" [Uls]; Mongolian: "Улсын хан", romanized: "Ulusyn khan") was the largest contiguous land empire in history. It was founded in 1206 by Genghis Khan, and at its peak under his grandson and successor, Ögedei Khan, it was the largest contiguous land empire in human history, covering an estimated 13 million km2, roughly one-sixth of the Earth's land area at the time, and from the Pacific Ocean to the Middle East, including most of present-day China, Korea, Russia, Central Asia, and Eastern Europe.

Karsid.passage: Karsid (Arabic: كرسد‎ ‎ ), also known as Karsid al-Shimali, is a village in southern Syria, administratively part of the Rif Dimashq Governorate, located southwest of Damascus. Nearby localities include al-Hajar al-Aswad to the north, al-Tadamon to the northeast, al-Qassabin to the east, al-Zabadani to the southeast, al-Husayn to the south, al-Shajara to the southwest and Deir Ali to the west. According to the Syria Central Bureau of Statistics (CBS), Karsid had a population of 6,945 in the 2004 census.

qae_pairs.question: What is the capital of the country that Karsid is in?
qae_pairs.explanation: Karsid is a village in southern Syria, administratively part of the Rif Dimashq Governorate, located southwest of Damascus. Nearby localities include al-Hajar al-Aswad to the north, al-Tadamon to the northeast, al-Qassabin to the east, al-Zabadani to the southeast, al-Husayn to the south, al-Shajara to the southwest and Deir Ali to the west.

the summer.passage: The summer is the season between the spring and the fall, in the northern hemisphere. In geology, the summer refers to the period of time between the spring equinox and the fall equinox, approximately from the 21st of March to the 22nd of September. In meteorology, the summer usually refers to the three calendar months with the highest and most widespread average temperature, in the Northern Hemisphere. In the Southern Hemisphere, the summer months are usually the opposite of those in the Northern Hemisphere.

qae_pairs.question: Which hemisphere has the summer that occurs after the spring equinox and before the fall equinox?
qae_pairs.explanation: The summer is the season between the spring and the fall, in the Northern Hemisphere.

qae_pairs.question: What is the summer?
qae_pairs.explanation: The summer is the season between the spring and the fall, in the northern hemisphere.

the winter.passage: In meteorology, the terms "winter", "summer", and "holiday" are often used in a relative sense to refer to the period of the year when the weather conditions prevail over a certain location, rather than a specific date.

qae_pairs.question: Which of the following is true about the winter in the United States?
qae_pairs.explanation: The winter in the United States is the period of the year when the weather conditions prevail over a certain location, rather than a specific date.

Sydney.passage: Sydney is Australia's largest city, its oldest colonial city, and the state capital of New South Wales. Located on Australia's east coast, the metropolis surrounds the world's largest natural harbour and sprawls towards the Blue Mountains. Sydney was founded as a British penal colony on 26 January 1788 within the then-named Port Jackson, and developed as a city due to its rich natural resources and strategic location. It is one of the world's most multicultural and cosmopolitan cities, and is classified as an alpha-world city. Sydney is ranked highly in many categories, such as economic, cultural, educational, environmental, and political stability. It is one of the world's most expensive cities to live in and has one of the highest living standards globally. It is one of the top ten most liveable cities in the world according to the Economist Intelligence Unit. The Sydney central business district stands on an artificial island, bounded by the Parramatta and Lane Cove rivers. The Sydney Harbour National Park, located in the central business district, is the largest urban national park in the world. Sydney is a major global city, and has been listed as the world's top city for expat employees on international surveys. It is the second-most populated city in Oceania and the eighth-most populated city in the world. It is one of two Australian cities with more than five million inhabitants (the other one being Melbourne).

qae_pairs.question: What is the capital of the state that Sydney is in?
qae_pairs.explanation: The capital of the state that Sydney is in is Melbourne.

qae_pairs.question: Which year did Sydney become a penal colony?
qae_pairs.explanation: Sydney was founded as a British penal colony on 26 January 1788.

qae_pairs.question: What is the capital of the Australian state that is home to the city of Sydney?
qae_pairs.explanation: Sydney is the capital of the Australian state of New South Wales.

Rakovsko.passage: In the 14th century, a Slavic settlement named Rakov was located on the site of Rakovsko. The village was mentioned in the records of the Kingdom of Bohemia in 1420 and again in 1431. The first written mention of Rakovsko itself dates to 1445. In 1420 the settlement had a population of 40 people, and in 1431 it had a population of 40 people. In the 1420s, the village was owned by the Lords of Kladsko. In the late 1420s, the Lords of Kladsko sold the village to the Lords of Rakov. In 1431 the Lords of Rakov sold the village to Jan of Cieszyn. In 1445, the village was owned by Władysław I the Elbow-high.

qae_pairs.question: How many years after the 1420s was Rakovsko sold to the Lords of Rakov?
qae_pairs.explanation: In the late 1420s, the Lords of Kladsko sold the village to the Lords of Rakov. In 1445, the village was owned by Władysław I the Elbow-high.

qae_pairs.question: What year was the village of Rakovsko sold to the Lords of Rakov?
qae_pairs.explanation: In 1431 the Lords of Rakov sold the village to Jan of Cieszyn.

qae_pairs.question: What is the name of the entity that Rakovsko is in?
qae_pairs.explanation: Rakovsko is located in the Kingdom of Bohemia.

qae_pairs.question: What year was Rakovsko first mentioned in the records?
qae_pairs.explanation: In 1445, the village was owned by Władysław I the Elbow-high.

Central Europe.passage: Central Europe (Central European Region or CET) is a subregion of Europe, consisting of the middle of the European continent. Central Europe is situated mostly in the middle and upper parts of the continent, and is bordered on almost all sides by mountain ranges. The largest cities in Central Europe are Prague, Warsaw, Bratislava, Budapest, Vienna, and Zagreb.

qae_pairs.question: How many cities in Central Europe have a population of less than 100,000?
qae_pairs.explanation: Bratislava is the only city in Central Europe with a population of less than 100,000.

qae_pairs.question: Which city in Central Europe has a larger population than Warsaw and Bratislava combined?
qae_pairs.explanation: Budapest has a larger population than Warsaw and Bratislava combined.
